overview: This measure has been substantially amended to establish a concrete effective date of January 1, 2026, for the pharmacy technician registration program, replacing the previous placeholder date. The bill now also includes a specific exemption from the sunrise analysis requirements by the Office of the Auditor. These changes signal the intent to implement the program, which will require pharmacy technicians to be registered with the Board of Pharmacy to protect public health and safety.
appropriations: Unlike the previous version, which had no immediate need for funding, this measure will now require an appropriation of funds to the Department of Commerce and Consumer Affairs. These funds will be necessary for the Board of Pharmacy to establish and administer the new registration program. The specific amount has not been determined in the documents provided.
assumptions_and_methodology: The primary assumption has shifted from no fiscal impact to a definite fiscal impact beginning in FY26. Calculations for revenue and expenditures are no longer theoretical and must be based on the program's implementation on January 1, 2026. The fiscal impact will depend on the final number of technicians who register with the Board of Pharmacy.
agency_impact: The indefinite deferral of agency impact has been eliminated; the Board of Pharmacy will now face a significant and immediate increase in its administrative workload. Responsibilities will include developing rules, creating and processing applications, and establishing enforcement procedures ahead of the January 1, 2026 start date. This will necessitate the allocation of new staffing and resources.
economic_impact: The previously nullified economic effects are now expected to be realized starting in 2026. Pharmacy technicians will incur costs associated with registration fees, while the public is expected to benefit from enhanced patient safety and increased accountability. This measure aligns Hawaii with national standards, potentially professionalizing the workforce.
policy_impact: The measure's policy implications are no longer moot; it will actively establish a regulatory framework for pharmacy technicians, aligning Hawaii with every other state. The new exemption from the sunrise analysis requirement underscores the legislative priority of implementing this public safety measure without further procedural delay. This solidifies the state's oversight role in the pharmacy profession.
revenue_sources: The collection of revenue is no longer indefinitely postponed. Beginning January 1, 2026, the Board of Pharmacy will begin collecting registration fees from pharmacy technicians. This fee-based revenue stream is intended to offset the administrative costs of the new regulatory program.
six_year_fiscal_implications: In contrast to the previous version, this measure now has direct fiscal implications within the six-year planning period. Startup costs will be incurred in FY26 to launch the registration program. Beginning in FY26 and continuing through FY31, there will be recurring administrative costs for the Board of Pharmacy related to staffing, compliance, and enforcement. These costs will be partially or fully offset by recurring revenue generated from biennial registration fees collected from pharmacy technicians. The program is expected to be fully operational with ongoing costs and revenues throughout the six-year period.
operating_revenue_impact: The measure will now have a direct positive impact on the operating revenue of the Board of Pharmacy. Revenue generation from technician registration fees will commence in the second half of FY26. This creates a new, recurring revenue stream that was previously not anticipated within the fiscal horizon.
fiscal_implications_after_6_years: The program's fiscal implications are no longer theoretical and will continue beyond the initial six-year period. Ongoing annual operating costs for program administration and enforcement by the Board of Pharmacy are expected. These long-term costs will be sustained by the recurring biennial registration fees collected from pharmacy technicians.
updates_from_previous_fiscal_note: The most significant update is the change in the effective date from a placeholder of July 1, 3000, to a firm implementation date of January 1, 2026, thereby activating immediate and ongoing fiscal impacts. Consequently, the measure now necessitates appropriations for the Board of Pharmacy and will generate revenue through registration fees. A new provision has also been added to exempt the measure from the sunrise analysis requirement, signaling intent for swift implementation.
